briefOverview: A national prayer asks God to vindicate Israel among the nations and renew his wonders, followed by maxims on discernment and the value of a good spouse and stable household.
summary: The chapter opens with a plea for God’s compassion toward Israel and a call for him to display his power so that the nations acknowledge there is no God but him. The speaker asks God to renew signs and wonders, judge hostile nations, and hasten the time of deliverance, gathering all the tribes of Jacob and restoring Jerusalem and Zion. He petitions God to confirm the words of former prophets, reward those who endure, and bless the people in the way of justice so all the earth knows God. The tone then shifts to wisdom sayings: just as the palate tests food, an understanding heart discerns false words; a corrupt heart causes grief, but the experienced resist it. The final verses commend the surpassing worth of a good wife who brings joy, comfort, and stability to a household, warning that life without such support is vulnerable and unsettled.
externalContext: Sirach (Ecclesiasticus) was composed in early 2nd century BCE Jerusalem by Ben Sira during the Hellenistic period, when Judea lived under foreign imperial powers. Jewish identity centered on the temple, Torah, and hopes for God’s vindication amid pressure from surrounding nations. The prayer for regathering the tribes reflects post-exilic hopes for full restoration after the Babylonian exile and subsequent dispersions. The emphasis on Jerusalem, Zion, and priestly blessing reflects the centrality of temple worship and the Aaronic priesthood in Judean religious life.
externalReferences: The plea that God be sanctified among the nations parallels Ezekiel’s promise that God will vindicate his holy name before the nations (Ezekiel 36:23). The request to gather all the tribes of Jacob reflects restoration prophecies such as Isaiah 11:12 and Ezekiel 37:21–22. Calling Israel God’s “firstborn” echoes Exodus 4:22, and invoking the blessing “of Aaron” recalls the priestly blessing of Numbers 6:24–26. Appeals for renewed “signs and wonders” recall the Exodus traditions (e.g., Exodus 7:3–5; Psalm 105:26–27).

sectionTitles.title: Value of a good wife and home

practicalQuestions: How can I pray for justice in a way that seeks God’s honor rather than personal revenge?
What practices help me discern truth from flattering or deceptive words?
In what ways can I contribute to the stability and rest of my household and community?
How might I honor and cultivate relationships that bring wisdom, comfort, and mutual support?
Where do I see a need for God to ‘renew his signs’ today, and how can I remain faithful while waiting?
uncertainAreas: The degree to which the judgment language (e.g., verses 8–12) is hyperbolic prayer poetry versus literal expectation is unclear. The abrupt shift from national prayer (1–19) to household maxims (20–28) raises questions about original compilation or editorial arrangement. Verse 23 is difficult: the line about a woman and daughters may reflect a comparative proverb whose precise nuance is hard to determine in translation.
